title: Objective
text:
Objective
Understanding and mitigating the causes of screwworm (Cochliomyia hominivorax) attacks on the mountain tapirs (Tapirus pinchaque).






NoteSpecifically, we intend to:




Conduct a census of domestic dogs in the communities surrounding the protected areas (Nevados National Natural Park and Otún Quimbaya Flora and Fauna Sanctuary).
Conduct a study within the protected areas (Nevados National Natural Park and Otún Quimbaya Flora and Fauna Sanctuary) to detect the presence of the mountain tapir, the screwworm, and other fly species.
Generate baseline data on the interactions between the mountain tapir and the screwworm, using camera traps, acoustic devices, co-occurrence models, and interviews.
Implement communication, education, training, and knowledge management strategies in the tapir’s distribution area, engaging local residents and visitors to the protected areas, to reduce the pressures on the tapir.


















Installation of Camera Traps

title: About
text:
This project is an initiative of the The IUCN/SSC Tapir Specialist Group (TSG) and contributes to the objectives of monitoring, prevention, surveillance and conservation of the Mountain Tapir (Tapirus pinchaque) in Los Nevados National Natural Park and the Otún Quimbaya Flora and Fauna Sanctuary, and helps to implement the: Mountain Tapir (Tapirus pinchaque) Conservation Program in the National Natural Parks of Colombia, by establishing a baseline of the Tapir’s occupancy in the Otún Quimbaya Flora and Fauna Sanctuary and Los Nevados National Natural Park.
This project is funded by: Mike Dee Mountain Tapir Conservation Fund, The IUCN SSC Tapir Specialist Group, Patricia Medici, LA Zoo, Zoologico de Cali and Minot Zoo.
